availability.p: For internal use by the Faclair na Gàidhlig/DASG projects

note.p: This could be an otherwise unattested adjective based on áthaba (e.g. "athabhuidh{iocht}"), meaning "helebore-like".
If the syntax here is meant to parallel previous lines, the scribe may understand "connuirc" to be the verbal noun.
This could mean the shore of (the isle of) Coll or simply a description ("the shore of hazels"). If "Tráigh Coll" is a some other placename elsewhere, I have not been able to identify it.

The scribe has inserted an "e" into "fallach" to make "feallach". The meaning of the latter is unclear and the former makes for a better rhyme (: raghnallach). However, the amended line is saying that Mag Uidhir is not "fallach" ("negligient"), when it is meant to be criticising him. The scribe may thus have been seeking a more positive adjective like "fíalach" ("modest"), for example.
Black, in his HDSG slips (Slip ID 0002809), reads "raghriuigh" but cannot identify or translate this. My tentative intepretation would translate "without the speech of frost" (i.e. clear speech).

The edge of the page runs right along the top of the letters in line 1, meaning some accents or abbreviation markers may have been lost. The most obviously required accents have been supplied. Only visible abbreviations are indicated.

This adjective is evidently related to fíad ("game") or fíad ("wild land") but the only available lemma for "fiadhach" means "hunting", which would not fit here syntactically unless one imagine a genitive plural along the clunky lines of "of the huntings" or suchlike.

This could be taken as the comparative of solus ("brighter the face of Ó Colla") or the noun, soillse ("sunshine"), in an implied copula construction ("The face of Ó Colla [is] sunshine"). Ther problem with the former is that "dech", in line b, already supplies a comparative.
